title: Leicester boss Claudio Ranieri admits he could be sensationally SACKED just months after winning shock Premier League title
text:
EFL 'It is possible' Leicester boss Claudio Ranieri admits he could be sensationally SACKED just months after winning shock Premier League title 
Foxes manager knows his job could be in danger if the Premier League champions drop further down the table on Sunday By JAMES ROBERTS Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments LEICESTER CITY manager Claudio Ranieri has conceded that his job could be in danger – just nine months after the Foxes’ incredible Premier League title win. 
The champions are just one point about the relegation zone and could be 17th by the time they kick off against Manchester United at 4pm. PA:Press Association Claudio Ranieri has come under increasing pressure during Leicester’s slide down the table Getty Images 3 Jamie Vardy and his Leicester team-mates have yet to score a league goal in 2017 
The Foxes’ poor form led Ranieri to admit that “everything [is possible]” when asked if he was unsackable. 
“Last season was completely different”, said the Leicester boss. 
“Every decision of the referee, every shot that hit the post was a goal, the first shot went in, the opponents missed a chance and penalties against us weren’t penalties and penalties for us were penalties.” Getty Images Leicester’s 1-0 defeat to Burnley on Tuesday night was their latest setback RELATED ARTICLES TEAM NEWS Leicester City vs Manchester United team news and line-ups: Anthony Martial looks set to miss out again with Phil Jones suffering from hamstring injury FOXES AND MOLES Is there a mole in the Leicester side secretly working to undermine struggling Claudio Ranieri? CHAMPS TO CHUMPS Leicester City have tumbled down the Premier League in dramatic fashion... and it's down to TIREDNESS SAM BUSTER Burnley 1 Leicester 0: Late sub Sam Vokes fires controversial Clarets winner as champions fall further down table Going nowhere Leicester outcast Leonardo Ulloa has 'no hope' of leaving the Foxes this month despite going on strike 
Ranieri’s side are yet to score a league goal in 2017. 
They started the calendar year with a 0-0 draw against Middlesbrough, but have since slipped to three straight Premier League defeats. 
Beating Jose Mourinho’s men would be only their fourth domestic victory since October. 
Ranieri says Leicester's season hasn't been perfect like it was last year 
"I was waiting for this kind of season last season", the Italian revealed to Sky Sports . 
"Then we made something extraordinary, out of the world." 
"The fairytale has finished. Now it is the reality. Now you have to choose - if you are a loser, you say it's gone. If you aren't a loser you fight, you continue to fight, believe."
